en_first_half: “You're a hopeless romantic,” said Faber. “It would be funny if it were not serious. It's not books you need, it's some of the things that once were in books. The same things could be in the `parlour families' today. The same infinite detail and awareness could be projected through the radios and televisors, but are not. No, no, it's not books at all you're looking for! Take it where you can find it, in old phonograph records, old motion pictures, and in old friends; look for it
en_second_half: in nature and look for it in yourself. Books were only one type of receptacle where we stored a lot of things we were afraid we might forget. There is nothing magical in them at all. The magic is only in what books say, how they stitched the patches of the universe together into one garment for us. Of course you couldn't know this, of course you still can't understand what I mean when I say all this. You are intuitively right, that's what counts. Three things are missing.

They were more aware of their place in the world and more willing to explore the depths of human experience. That's what you're searching for, my friend, not just some dusty old books on a shelf. You want to feel the pulse of the past, to understand the people who came before us and the world they lived in. You want to be transported to a different time and place, to experience the beauty and the struggles of a bygone era. And that's exactly what you'll find in the old phonograph records, the old motion pictures, and the old friends who still hold onto the values and the spirit of a bygone age. It's not just about nostalgia, it's about understanding the present by looking at the past. It's about recognizing that the same human experiences, the same hopes and fears, the same joys and sorrows, are still present today, even if the world around us has changed. And that's what you're searching for, my friend, a connection to the human experience that transcends time and space.

La magia sólo está en lo que dicen los libros, en cómo unían los diversos aspectos del Universo hasta formar un conjunto para nosotros. Desde luego, usted no puede saber esto, sigue sin entender lo que quiero decir con mis palabras. Intuitivamente, tiene usted razón, y eso es lo que importa. Faltan tres cosas.

Usted está buscando algo más profundo, algo que no se puede encontrar en los libros, algo que solo se puede encontrar en la conexión humana, en la empatía y en la comprensión. Es por eso que necesita buscar en los lugares donde la gente se reúne para compartir sus historias, donde la nostalgia y la nostalgia se entrelazan, donde la gente comparte sus experiencias y sus conocimientos. Busque en los mercados de pulgas, en las tiendas de antigüedades, en las reuniones de aficionados, en las conversaciones en las cafeterías, en las historias de los abuelos, en las canciones de los músicos callejeros. en_results_raw: there was a fire in the house, I would have been the first to rush in and save it, but now I'm not so sure. The thought of those flames, the roar of the fire, the heat and the smoke, it's all so overwhelming. I've seen it happen to others, the way it consumes everything in its path, leaving nothing but ashes and ruin. And yet, I've also seen the beauty of a well-planned and executed fire, the way it can clear out the old and make way for the new. But what if it's not just a fire, what if it's something more? Something that threatens not just my home, but my very way of life?

es_results_raw: televisor, y ellos se divierten viendo películas y jugando videojuegos. Mi esposa se encarga de darles la cena y hacerles la cama. A veces, cuando están cansados, los envío a la cámara de los niños, donde duermen en sus camas individuales. Mi esposa y yo tenemos nuestra propia habitación, donde podemos relajarnos y disfrutar de un poco de privacidad. Aunque a veces me preocupa que los niños se sientan abandonados, pero mi esposa me dice que están bien y que necesitan espacio para crecer. En realidad, creo que ella tiene razón. Los niños necesitan aprender a ser independientes y a cuidar de sí mismos. Pero a veces, cuando estoy en la cámara de los niños, escuchando sus risas y sus conversaciones, me siento un poco nostálgico por los tiempos en que eran pequeños y necesitaban mi atención constante. Me pregunto si algún día dejarán de necesitarme tanto y si podré volver a ser el centro de atención. Pero por ahora, estoy contento con la vida que tenemos y con la forma en que hemos organizado nuestras rutinas. Me siento afortunado de tener una esposa que entiende mis necesidades y que se esfuerza por mantener la armonía en nuestra familia.

en_first_half: One of them had to stop burning. The sun wouldn't, certainly. So it looked as if it had to be Montag and the people he had worked with until a few short hours ago. Somewhere the saving and putting away had to begin again and someone had to do the saving and keeping,
en_second_half: one way or another, in books, in records, in people's heads, any way at all so long as it was safe, free from moths, silver-fish, rust and dry-rot, and men with matches. en_results: but Montag, with his new perspective, couldn't help but feel a sense of irony in the situation. en_results_raw: but Montag, with his new perspective, couldn't help but feel a sense of irony in the situation. He had spent his entire career as a fireman, suppressing the very thing that was now necessary for the survival of humanity. The thought sent a shiver down his spine as he gazed out at the flames, now dwindling to a smoldering ember. The people he had worked with, the ones he had called colleagues, were now the ones who had to take up the mantle of preservation. It was a role reversal that Montag couldn't quite wrap his head around, but he knew it was a necessary one. The world was changing, and he was determined to be a part of it, even if it meant going against everything he had once believed in. As he stood there, the weight of his new responsibility settled upon him, he knew that he had to make a choice: to continue down the path of destruction, or to join the fight for preservation. The fate of humanity hung in the balance, and Montag was no longer just a fireman, but a guardian of the future.

es_results_raw: no era tan amargo como lo que había imaginado, pero el sabor era extraño y le hizo sentir una sensación de vacío en el estómago. Montag se preguntó qué era lo que estaba bebiendo, pero no se atrevió a preguntar. Los hombres le miraban con una expresión seria, como si esperaran algo de él. El jefe de la estación, que estaba sentado en una silla de madera, se levantó y se acercó a Montag. "¿Te sientes mejor?", le preguntó con una sonrisa forzada. Montag asintió con la cabeza, pero no estaba seguro de si estaba mejor o peor. El jefe de la estación se sentó de nuevo y comenzó a hablar en voz baja, como si temiera que alguien los escuchara. "Queremos que sepas que estamos aquí para ayudarte, Montag. Queremos que sepas que no estás solo. Pero también queremos que sepas que hay cosas que no puedes saber, cosas que no puedes entender. Y hay cosas que no puedes decir. ¿Entendes?" Montag asintió con la cabeza, pero no estaba seguro de qué estaba pasando. ¿Qué era lo que no podía saber? ¿Qué era lo que no podía entender? ¿Qué era lo que no podía decir? La confusión se apoderó de él y se sintió como si estuviera flotando en un mar de incertidumbre.

en_first_half: Later, the men around Montag could not say if they had really seen anything. Perhaps the merest flourish of light and motion in the sky. Perhaps the bombs were there, and the jets, ten miles, five miles, one mile up, for the merest instant, like grain thrown over the heavens by a great sowing hand, and the bombs drifting with dreadful swiftness, yet sudden slowness, down upon the morning city they had left behind. The bombardment was to all intents and purposes finished, once the jets had sighted their target, alerted their bombardiers at five thousand
en_second_half: miles an hour; as quick as the whisper of a scythe the war was finished. Once the bomb-release was yanked it was over. Now, a full three seconds, all of the time in history, before the bombs struck, the enemy ships themselves were gone half around the visible world, like bullets in which a savage islander might not believe because they were invisible; yet the heart is suddenly shattered, the body falls in separate motions and the blood is astonished to be freed on the air; the brain squanders its few precious memories and, puzzled, dies.

en_results_raw: The city's skyline was a blur of smoke and fire, a chaotic tapestry of destruction, as the bombs detonated with deafening force, sending shockwaves through the air, and the jets, now mere specks in the distance, vanished into the clouds, their mission accomplished. The men around Montag stood frozen, their faces etched with a mix of awe and terror, as they struggled to comprehend the sheer scale of the devastation that had been wrought upon their once-thriving metropolis. The silence that followed was oppressive, punctuated only by the distant rumble of collapsing buildings and the anguished cries of the wounded. It was as if the very fabric of their reality had been torn asunder, leaving behind a scar that would take years to heal. The city, once a beacon of progress and innovation, now lay in ruins, a testament to the destructive power of war and the futility of human endeavor. As the dust settled, the men around Montag began to stir, their faces set with determination, their eyes burning with a fierce resolve to rebuild and reclaim their shattered world. But for now, they stood frozen, their minds reeling from the horror they had witnessed, their hearts heavy with the knowledge of what they had lost.
vi_first_half: Về sau, những người quanh Montag không thể nói liệu họ có thực tình thấy cái gì không. Có lẽ chỉ là chút ánh sáng và chuyển động nhoáng qua trên bầu trời. Có lẽ có bom ở đó, có những máy bay, mười dặm, năm dặm, một dặm trên đầu, chỉ trong khoảnh khắc, như hạt giống do một bàn tay khổng lồ gieo vãi khắp các tầng trời, và bao nhiêu là bom lùa qua nhanh đến ghê người, nhưng rồi lại đột ngột chậm lại rơi xuống thành phố buổi sáng mà họ bỏ lại sau lưng. Cuộc ném bom gần như đã kết thúc, một khi đám máy bay đã nhìn ra mục tiêu, báo cho người đảm trách ném bom với tốc độ năm ngàn dặm một
vi_second_half: giờ; nhanh như cú vèo của một lưỡi hái chiến tranh kết thúc. Một khi cửa khoang bom được bung ra, chiến tranh chấm dứt. Giờ, trọn ba giây, toàn bộ thời gian trong lịch sử, trước khi bom chạm mục tiêu, bản thân các tàu địch đã đi quá nửa đường qua thế giới hữu hình, như những viên đạn mà một cư dân hoang dã nơi hải đảo có thể không tin là có bởi chúng vô hình; song trái tim đột ngột vỡ ra từng mảnh, cơ thể rã ra thành những phần chuyển động riêng rẽ và toàn bộ máu sững sờ thấy mình được giải phóng trong không khí; bộ óc tung vãi những ký ức quý báu ít ỏi của nó, và rồi, hoang mang, chết.

Mientras caminaba entre las ruinas, vio a los supervivientes que huían en todas direcciones, algunos con heridas sangrientas, otros con niños llorosos en brazos, y otros simplemente con la mirada vacía y perdida. El silencio que se había seguido al bombardeo era opresivo, y Montag se sintió como si estuviera caminando en un sueño, donde nada tenía sentido y todo parecía irreal. El mundo había cambiado, y él no sabía si podría adaptarse a este nuevo orden.

en_results_raw: and sped off into the night, leaving behind a trail of faintly glowing footprints that seemed to mock Montag as he stood there, frozen in the darkness. The books, it seemed, had been more than just mere objects, for they now lay scattered all around him, their pages fluttering in the breeze like the wings of a thousand restless birds. The sound of their pages rustling was like a chorus of whispers, a cacophony of forgotten knowledge and half-remembered truths. Montag's mind reeled as he stumbled through the darkness, his eyes straining to adjust to the sudden absence of light. The stair-well seemed to stretch on forever, a seemingly endless tunnel of blackness that threatened to consume him whole. And yet, even as he felt himself being pulled down into its depths, Montag couldn't shake the feeling that he was being watched, that unblinking eyes were trained on him from the shadows, waiting for him to make his next move. es_results_raw: pero ahora, con la llegada de la era de la libertad de información, los libros habían adquirido un valor inestimable, y la gente estaba dispuesta a luchar por ellos. Montag, que había sido un ferviente defensor de la destrucción de libros, se encontró a sí mismo en una situación incómoda, rodeado de una multitud de personas que luchaban por salvar los volúmenes de una biblioteca que estaba siendo demolida. La Policía, que había sido entrenada para perseguir a los disidentes, ahora parecía estar luchando por mantener el control en una sociedad que cada vez más estaba cuestionando la autoridad. La multitud, compuesta por personas de todas las edades y clases sociales, estaba unida en su deseo de preservar la literatura y la historia, y Montag se encontró a sí mismo preguntándose si había estado equivocado todo este tiempo. Mientras ascendía la escalera, tropezando con los demás, se le ocurrió una idea: ¿y si la verdadera revolución no era la destrucción de los libros, sino su preservación? ¿Y si la verdadera forma de liberar la mente era leer, en lugar de quemar? La idea le hizo sentir una mezcla de emoción y miedo, y se preguntó qué pasaría si se uniera a la multitud y se uniera a la lucha por la libertad de información.

en_first_half: “You're a hopeless romantic,” said Faber. “It would be funny if it were not serious. It's not books you need, it's some of the things that once were in books. The same things could be in the `parlour families' today. The same infinite detail and awareness could be projected through the radios and televisors, but are not. No, no, it's not books at all you're looking for! Take it where you can find it, in old phonograph records, old motion pictures, and in old friends; look for it
en_second_half: in nature and look for it in yourself. Books were only one type of receptacle where we stored a lot of things we were afraid we might forget. There is nothing magical in them at all. The magic is only in what books say, how they stitched the patches of the universe together into one garment for us. Of course you couldn't know this, of course you still can't understand what I mean when I say all this. You are intuitively right, that's what counts. Three things are missing.
en_results: all the time, in the way people speak, in the way they move, in the way they think. It's not just about the physical objects, but about the spirit they represent. They were more aware of their place in the world and more willing to explore the depths of human experience. That's what you're searching for, my friend, not just some dusty old books on a shelf. The spirit of a bygone era, a time when people were more connected to each other and to the world around them. They were more aware of their place in the world and more willing to explore the depths of human experience. That's what you're searching for, my friend, not just some dusty old books on a shelf. You want to feel the pulse of the past, to understand the people who came before us and the world they lived in. You want to be transported to a different time and place, to experience the beauty and the struggles of a bygone era. And that's exactly what you'll find in the old phonograph records, the old motion pictures, and the old friends who still hold onto the values and the spirit of a bygone age. It's not just about nostalgia, it's about understanding the present by looking at the past. It's about recognizing that the same human experiences, the same hopes and fears, the same joys and sorrows, are still present today, even if the world around us has changed. And that's what you're searching for, my friend, a connection to the human experience that transcends time and space.

es_first_half: —Es usted un romántico sin esperanza —dijo Faber—. Resultaría divertido si no fuese tan grave. No son libros lo que usted necesita, sino alguna de las cosas que en un tiempo estuvieron en los libros. El mismo detalle infinito y las mismas enseñanzas podrían ser proyectados a través de radios y televisores, pero no lo son. No, no: no son libros lo que usted está buscando. Búsquelo donde pueda encontrarlo, en viejos discos, en viejas películas y en viejos amigos; búsquelo en la
es_second_half: Naturaleza y búsquelo por sí mismo. Los libros sólo eran un tipo de receptáculo donde almacenábamos una serie de cosas que temíamos olvidar. No hay nada mágico en ellos. La magia sólo está en lo que dicen los libros, en cómo unían los diversos aspectos del Universo hasta formar un conjunto para nosotros. Desde luego, usted no puede saber esto, sigue sin entender lo que quiero decir con mis palabras. Intuitivamente, tiene usted razón, y eso es lo que importa. Faltan tres cosas.
es_results: memoria de los que han vivido antes que nosotros. La verdadera sabiduría no se encuentra en las páginas impresas, sino en las historias que se transmiten de boca a boca, en las leyendas que se han ido acumulando con el tiempo, en las canciones que se cantan en torno a un campfire. Es allí donde se encuentra la auténtica esencia de la humanidad, no en los libros que se escriben para ser leídos, sino en las historias que se cuentan para ser compartidas. Y es allí donde usted debe
es_results_raw: memoria de los que han vivido antes que nosotros. La verdadera sabiduría no se encuentra en las páginas impresas, sino en las historias que se transmiten de boca a boca, en las leyendas que se han ido acumulando con el tiempo, en las canciones que se cantan en torno a un campfire. Es allí donde se encuentra la auténtica esencia de la humanidad, no en los libros que se escriben para ser leídos, sino en las historias que se cuentan para ser compartidas. Y es allí donde usted debe buscar, en el corazón de la gente, en las historias que se han ido acumulando con el paso del tiempo, en las canciones que se cantan en torno a un campfire, en las leyendas que se han ido transmitiendo de generación en generación. Pero, ¿qué es lo que realmente está buscando? ¿Qué es lo que lo lleva a buscar en los lugares más oscuros y olvidados de la historia? ¿Es la búsqueda de la verdad, o simplemente la búsqueda de algo que lo llene el vacío que siente en su corazón? ¿O es algo más profundo, algo que se relaciona con su propia identidad, con su propia existencia? ¿Qué es lo que lo hace sentir que necesita algo más, algo que no puede encontrar en la vida moderna? ¿Es la conexión con algo más grande que él mismo, con algo que lo trascienda a él mismo? ¿O es simplemente la búsqueda de una sensación de pertenencia, de ser parte de algo más grande que él mismo? ¿Qué es lo que realmente está buscando, y qué es lo que lo llevará a encontrarlo? Solo él lo sabe, pero es claro que su búsqueda no es trivial, y que lo que está buscando es algo que lo cambiará para siempre.

en_results_raw: but it's a small price to pay for the gift of life. Besides, I've seen many women who've had natural births and they're not always as easy as they're made out to be. I'd do it all over again in a heartbeat if I had to. en_results_raw: that the world they know is already crumbling beneath their feet, and the ground they stand on is nothing but a thin layer of dust and ashes. They are so convinced that their way of life is the only way, that they will never stop to think about the consequences of their actions. But the truth is, Montag, that their world is built on a foundation of sand, and it will not stand the test of time. They are so blinded by their own arrogance that they cannot see the writing on the wall, the warning signs that their world is on the brink of collapse. They are so confident that they will run on for ever, but they won't run on. They don't know that the fire they have been using to warm their homes and cook their meals is the same fire that will one day consume them. They don't know that the machines they have created to make their lives easier will one day turn against them. They don't know that the very things they have been using to control and manipulate others will one day be used against them. They are so confident that they will run on for ever, but they won't run on. They don't know that their world is already in its final stages, and that the end is near. Montag's eyes scanned the washroom, taking in the worn sinks and the faded advertisements on the walls. He felt a shiver run down his spine as he realized the gravity of the situation. The attendants, usually so cheerful and friendly, now looked like they were in a state of panic. One of them, a burly man with a thick beard, was pacing back and forth, his eyes fixed on the radio. The other attendant, a younger man with a scruffy beard, was on the phone, his voice hushed as he spoke to someone on the other end. Montag's mind was racing with questions. What did this mean for his community? For his family? For the world at large? He knew he had to get back to his Beetle and find out more. He quickly washed his hands and left the washroom, his heart pounding in his chest.

en_results_raw: was a tiny, insignificant speck on the vast, grey pavement, as he careened wildly through the deserted streets, his footsteps echoing off the buildings in a maddening rhythm that seemed to match the frantic beat of his own racing heart. The world around him seemed to be spinning, colors blurring together in a kaleidoscope of chaos, as he stumbled and staggered through the desolate landscape, his mind a jumble of fragmented thoughts and half-formed emotions. He was a man lost in a sea of madness, driven by some unseen force that propelled him forward with a momentum that seemed impossible to stop. The sound of his own ragged breathing was the only thing that seemed to anchor him to reality, a reminder that he was still alive, still human, even as his mind and body seemed to be tearing themselves apart. And yet, even as he ran, a small, rational part of him knew that he couldn't keep this up for much longer - the exhaustion was building, the panic was growing, and soon he would have to face the consequences of his actions. But for now, he just kept running, driven by a desperate need to escape, to flee from the darkness that was closing in around him like a suffocating shroud.

en_results_raw: had been running for what felt like an eternity, his footsteps echoing off the cold, grey walls of the city, the only sound breaking the oppressive silence that had fallen over the once-thriving metropolis. The darkness seemed to swallow him whole, a living, breathing entity that threatened to consume him at any moment. His heart pounded in his chest, a frantic drumbeat that seemed to synchronize with the pounding of his feet on the pavement. He had to keep moving, to keep running, or risk being caught by the very people he had once called friends. The thought sent a shiver down his spine, and he quickened his pace, his breath coming in ragged gasps as he disappeared into the night, lost in a sea of shadows.

The sound echoed through the empty streets, a haunting melody that seemed to match the rhythm of Montag's footsteps as he ran further and further away from the house, the valise bouncing against his leg with each step. The rain-soaked air clung to him, weighing him down, but he didn't dare look back, fearing what he might see. The rain pounded against him, a relentless drumbeat that seemed to grow louder with every step, and Montag knew he was running out of time.

en_results_raw: but Montag, with his new perspective, couldn't help but feel a sense of irony in the situation. He had spent his entire career as a fireman, suppressing the very thing that was now necessary for the survival of humanity. The thought sent a shiver down his spine as he gazed out at the flames, now dwindling to a smoldering ember. The people he had worked with, the ones he had called colleagues, were now the ones who had to take up the mantle of preservation. It was a role reversal that Montag couldn't quite wrap his head around, but he knew it was a necessary one. The world was changing, and he was determined to be a part of it, even if it meant going against everything he had once believed in. As he stood there, the weight of his new responsibility settled upon him, he knew that he had to make a choice: to continue down the path of destruction, or to join the fight for preservation. The fate of humanity hung in the balance, and Montag was no longer just a fireman, but a guardian of the future.

The sensation was both exhilarating and unsettling, like a wild mustang that had been unleashed from its stable. He could feel his senses heightening, his perception of time and space expanding, and his mind racing with thoughts and ideas that seemed to come from nowhere and everywhere at the same time. The faces of the people around him began to blur and distort, their features melting like wax in a furnace, and he felt himself becoming one with the universe, connected to every molecule and atom, every star and planet. The world was a vast, intricate web, and he was the thread that bound it all together. He felt a sense of awe and wonder at the sheer magnitude of it all, and a sense of trepidation at the unknown consequences of this newfound awareness. The liquid was still burning his tongue and the roof of his mouth, but he didn't care. He was beyond pain, beyond fear, beyond the boundaries of the human experience. es_results_raw: no era tan amargo como lo que había imaginado, pero el sabor era extraño y le hizo sentir una sensación de vacío en el estómago. Montag se preguntó qué era lo que estaba bebiendo, pero no se atrevió a preguntar. Los hombres le miraban con una expresión seria, como si esperaran algo de él. El jefe de la estación, que estaba sentado en una silla de madera, se levantó y se acercó a Montag. "¿Te sientes mejor?", le preguntó con una sonrisa forzada. Montag asintió con la cabeza, pero no estaba seguro de si estaba mejor o peor. El jefe de la estación se sentó de nuevo y comenzó a hablar en voz baja, como si temiera que alguien los estuviera escuchando. "Queremos que sepas que estamos aquí para ayudarte, Montag. Queremos que sepas que no estás solo. Pero también queremos que sepas que hay cosas que no puedes saber, cosas que no puedes entender. Y hay cosas que no puedes decir. ¿Entendes?" Montag asintió con la cabeza, pero no estaba seguro de qué estaba pasando. ¿Qué era lo que no podía saber? ¿Qué era lo que no podía entender? ¿Qué era lo que no podía decir? Montag se sintió confundido y asustado, pero también se sintió agradecido por la atención que le estaban prestando. Se sintió como si estuviera en un lugar seguro, como si estuviera en un lugar donde podía ser él mismo. Pero ¿qué era lo que estaba pasando? ¿Qué era lo que estaba sucediendo en ese lugar? ¿Qué era lo que estaba a punto de descubrir? Montag se sintió como si estuviera a punto de descubrir un secreto, un secreto que cambiaría su vida para siempre.

en_first_half: “Listen,” said Granger, taking his arm, and walking with him, holding aside the bushes to let him pass. “When I was a boy my grandfather died, and he was a sculptor. He was also a very kind man who had a lot of love to give the world, and he helped clean up the slum in our town; and he made toys for us and he did a million things in his lifetime; he was always busy with his hands. And when he died, I suddenly realized I wasn't crying for him at all, but for the things he did. I cried because he would never do them again, he would never carve another piece of wood or help
en_second_half: us raise doves and pigeons in the back yard or play the violin the way he did, or tell us jokes the way he did. He was part of us and when he died, all the actions stopped dead and there was no one to do them just the way he did. He was individual. He was an important man. I've never gotten over his death. Often I think, what wonderful carvings never came to birth because he died. How many jokes are missing from the world, and how many homing pigeons untouched by his hands. He shaped the world. He did things to the world. The world was bankrupted of ten million fine actions the night he passed on.”
en_results: make another toy or paint another picture. And I realized that it wasn't the man I missed, but the love and the kindness he showed me through his actions. It was the memories of him doing those things that I cherished, not the man himself. It's a lesson that has stayed with me throughout my life, and one that I try to pass on to others whenever I can. I think that's why I became a teacher, to help people understand the value of love and kindness, and to show them that it's the actions we take that truly matter, not just the people we love. And that's why I've dedicated my life to helping those in need, to spreading love and kindness wherever I go. It's a big responsibility, but one that I'm proud to take on. And I hope that one day, people will look back on my life and remember not just the things I did, but the love and kindness I showed them through my actions. That's the true legacy we leave behind, not just our accomplishments or our possessions, but the love and kindness we share with others. And that's what I hope to leave behind when I'm gone, a world that's a little bit brighter, a little bit kinder, because of the love and kindness I showed to those around me.

Nunca me he sobrepuesto a su muerte. A menudo, pienso en las tallas maravillosas que nunca han cobrado forma a causa de su muerte. Cuántos chistes faltan al mundo, y cuántos pichones no sido tocados por sus manos. Configuró el mundo, hizo cosas en su beneficio. en_first_half: Later, the men around Montag could not say if they had really seen anything. Perhaps the merest flourish of light and motion in the sky. Perhaps the bombs were there, and the jets, ten miles, five miles, one mile up, for the merest instant, like grain thrown over the heavens by a great sowing hand, and the bombs drifting with dreadful swiftness, yet sudden slowness, down upon the morning city they had left behind. The bombardment was to all intents and purposes finished, once the jets had sighted their target, alerted their bombardiers at five thousand
en_second_half: miles an hour; as quick as the whisper of a scythe the war was finished. Once the bomb-release was yanked it was over. Now, a full three seconds, all of the time in history, before the bombs struck, the enemy ships themselves were gone half around the visible world, like bullets in which a savage islander might not believe because they were invisible; yet the heart is suddenly shattered, the body falls in separate motions and the blood is astonished to be freed on the air; the brain squanders its few precious memories and, puzzled, dies.

en_results_raw: The city's skyline was a blur of smoke and fire, a chaotic tapestry of destruction, as the bombs detonated with deafening force, sending shockwaves through the air, and the jets, now mere specks in the distance, vanished into the clouds, their mission accomplished. The men around Montag stood frozen, their faces etched with a mix of awe and terror, as they struggled to comprehend the sheer scale of the devastation that had been wrought upon the city they had once called home. The silence that followed was oppressive, a heavy blanket that suffocated the senses, as the reality of the destruction slowly began to sink in. The once-thriving metropolis was now a smoldering ruin, a testament to the unforgiving power of war. The men's minds reeled as they tried to process the images that had been seared into their minds - the flames that engulfed the skyscrapers, the buildings reduced to rubble, the screams of the innocent, the cries of the dying. The world had changed forever, and Montag and his comrades knew that they would never be the same again. The city's destruction was a stark reminder of the horrors of war, a grim reminder of the devastating consequences of human conflict. As they stood there, frozen in shock, the men couldn't help but wonder what the future held, and whether they would ever be able to rebuild the shattered remnants of their world.

es_results_raw: terminado, y los hombres que estaban con Montag no podían evitar sentir un sentimiento de alivio y confusión al mismo tiempo. El humo y el polvo que se elevaban del suelo cubrían la vista, y el ruido de las explosiones y los gritos de los supervivientes se mezclaban en un cúmulo de terror y desesperación. Montag, que había estado tan seguro de sí mismo y de su misión, se sintió vacío y confundido, como si hubiera perdido su rumbo en un mar de destrucción. El mundo que había conocido había cambiado para siempre, y él no sabía si podría encontrar su lugar en él. Mientras caminaba entre las ruinas, vio a los supervivientes que huían en todas direcciones, algunos con heridas sangrientas, otros con niños llorosos en brazos, y otros simplemente con la mirada vacía y perdida. El silencio que se había seguido al bombardeo era opresivo, y Montag se sintió como si estuviera caminando en un sueño, donde nada tenía sentido y todo parecía irreal. El mundo había cambiado, y él no sabía si podría adaptarse a este nuevo orden.
